data.title: German intervention in the Spanish Civil War, 1936-1939
data.meta_description: German intervention in the Spanish Civil War, 1936-1939
data.text:
On 25 July 1936, Hitler’s Germany began an interventionist program in Spain on behalf of the insurgent Nacionales, under the leadership of General Francisco Franco. The relationship between Nazi Germany and Nationalist Spain was realpolitik state craft. The use of monetary wealth, diplomatic skill, and military assistance by Nazi Germany went to the prevention of communism and to shift the balance of power in Europe to favor those actively fighting against communism. The Nationalist Government and Nazi Germany stressed their sovereign rights to territory and citizens within the conflict, affirming themselves continuously as independent states. Therefore, Spain proceeded in realpolitik relations with Germany for Spanish interests, and vice versa for Germany. Nationalist interests were to administrate the Spanish state and remove all external influence. Germany’s interests were to shift the balance of power in Europe to its favor and the rearmament program by gaining raw material from Spain.

In examining Spanish-German relations during the war, it becomes evident that Germany did know how to find the way to the soul of neutral Spain. The overall aim of German activity in Spain was to ensure Spanish neutrality at all costs in order to prohibit Spain from joining the Entente. However, this often meant completely violating the country’s rights as a neutral in the European conflict. This becomes particularly evident when examining Germany’s attempts to disrupt the Allied economic war effort from Spain as much as possible. While widespread German press propaganda ensured heated debates amongst Francófilos and Germanófilos, German diplomats tried to influence important power brokers in Spain such as King Alfonso XIII. On one hand, German diplomats and agents bolstered Spain’s conservative and monarchist ruling elite, and on the other hand, Germany also supported and infiltrated Spanish workers organisations with the aim of agitating strike action which would negatively impact on Allied trade. The article will outline the main aspects of German interference in Spanish domestic affairs during the First World War and the destabilising effect this interference had on Spain's already highly fragile domestic situation.

This paper argues that immediately after the defeat of France in June 1940 the Germans missed an opportunity to engage Spain on their side, and possibly close Gibraltar to the British. For a variety of reasons, Hitler missed a potential opportunity that might have dramatically altered the course of the war.
